subject: Re: [junit] using JUnit for UI testing?

messageBody:
On Wed, 28 Feb 2001, Andy Kriger wrote:

> Is anyone out there using JUnit for UI testing? Can you describe the
> framework you have created to accomplish this? At a certain point UI test
> requires eyes on the product but how much have you been able to test up to
> that point?

I tend to build components, and test those components and their models.
I haven't been writing unit tests for the final UI display as of late,
the class library behind the UI has its own unit tests. (I'm writing
wizards using a wizard library.)

For the components, I have a selection of methods which trigger swing
methods, ie things like:

/**
* @param button
*/
public static void safeDoClick( final JButton button ) {
try {
SwingUtilities.invokeAndWait(
new Runnable() {
/**
* Main processing method for the AllTests object
*/
public void run() {
button.doClick();
}
}
);
} catch ( Exception ex ) {
ex.printStackTrace();
}
}

since my #1 self-induced-brain-fart is to call doClick on a button
that's already visible.

I have these for setText(), doClick(), (Jlist) setSelectedIndex(),
requestFocus(), getText() so far.

I use the above to programmatically exercise a UI component and verify
function by inspecting the results in the model. I also have some
hooks that allow my tests to add addtional event listeners and check
that the component generated the correct type and number of a specific
event.

I have rarely found it necessary to actually test the UI if I'm already
testing the model. Once case I do test is where a component takes
a parameter which defines something about the UI, ie horizontal
vs vertical layout. I'll write a test which checks that the result
follows the parameter. I'll also test that a component's actual size
when visible stays within predefined limits.
